loans.name: Idongi

texts.en: Idongi F. is currently in the business of baking and selling bread  and is requesting a loan to purchase more baking materials.  Idongi is 25 years old and is Married with a husband that is a business man. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a shop  BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more baking materials

loans.name: Oidov

texts.en:
Oidov is a 25-year-old young lady who lives with her husband and two children. Her two children are both still very young and they both go to kindergarden. The family lives in their own ger (nomadic housing tent) in Arkhangai province, Mongolia.

Oidov has had her own business selling meat and meat products since 2002. Her working capital was 20,000 tugrug (~15 USD) at first, but now it exceeds 120,000 tugrug (~90 USD). Her husband helps in generating their famliy income by selling firewood.

Oidov’s ultimate goal for now is to increase her meat sales and to have her own work place in which to sell her products. She says: "I work hard to better my children's lives. All the money I earn will be spent on my children’s education."

Oidov is requesting a 200,000 tugrug to purchase more meat and meat products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more meat and meat products to sell

loans.name: Mạnh's Group

texts.en:
Mạnh Thị N. grows vegetables and sells them in the market. She was born in 1960. Her husband has died. She has two children. She has a monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND. She is active and friendly. She has taken part in SEDA for four years. This time, she wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND to buy seedlings and fertilizer. ID: 010114010002

About the other borrowers in the group: Tám Thị Trần grows vegetables. She was born in 1959. She has three children. She has a monthly income of about 2.500.000 VND. She wants to borrow 5.450.000 VND to buy vegetables to resell. ID: 010114010016

Thủy Thị N. is a worker and she raises chicken. She was born in 1977. She wants to borrow 4.578.000 VND to buy feed for her chickens. ID: 010114010019

Nghiệp Thị N. grows vegetables and raises pigs. She was born in 1959. She has two children. She wants to borrow 5.450.000 VND to buy hog feed and fertilizer. ID: 010114010021

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Aya

texts.en:
Aya S., 25, currently in the business of selling beer at the bar and requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer, is married to a peasant and is the mother of three children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children and provide them with scholastic materials.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Tserenbat

texts.en:
Tserenbat M., a 22-year-old single man, lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home, in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. A very hard-working young man, he operates an auto spare-parts trading business in his town which he began in 2000 in partnership with his father with capital of 300,000 tugrugs ($210 USD) . After years of success and growth, Tserenbat went off on his own in 2008, and today, his working capital exceeds 1,500,000 tugrugs ($1,050 USD). From his business profits he bought a car, and he is now working hard to further grow his business.

As auto parts make up a large portion of his sales, Tserenbat hopes to take advantage of the rapidly-growing number of Mongolians who own cars. He is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug ($1,750 USD) loan to purchase more machinery parts for his business. His dream is to one day own his auto parts store.

loans.use: To purchase more machinery parts

loans.name: Tuyasaihan

texts.en: Tuyasaihan is a 37 year old, single mother who lives with her 2 children and mother in their own ger in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. Her two children both attend high school while her mother stays at home during the day. Tuyasaihan believes that education is the most important factor to having a happy life and she wants her children to have the best education that she can provide for them. She has been a cook for many years and, because of this, she decided to run a cafe in 2008 by renting a work place. At first, her working capital was 500 000 tugrug (~350 USD) but has now grown to over 1 200 000 tugrug (~840 USD).  Her wish is to one day have her own cafe. Tuyasaihan is requesting a 1 500 000 tugrug (~1050USD) loan to buy materials, tools and ingredients so that she can expand her cafe's menu.

loans.use: to buy materials, tools and ingredients

loans.name: Unutsetseg

texts.en: O. Unurtsetseg is 39 years old and lives in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She is single and shares a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home, with her mother. She currently operates a small children's clothing business in his town by importing clothing from China and selling it at the local market. After leaving a job as a saleswoman, Unurtsetseg started her children's clothing business in 2007 with capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD). Due to her hard work and persistence, she has found much success. Today, her working capital exceeds 600,000 tugrugs (~420 USD). For the future, Unurtsetseg hopes to grow his business further by offering a wider variety of products. Her mission is to deliver the highest quality clothing possible to the children in her community. She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan to purchase more children's clothing items for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more children's clothing items

loans.name: Phien's Group

texts.en:
Phiên Thị Nguyễn was born in 1969. (id: 010117050026). She lives in Dan Mo, Uy No, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. Her husband is a builder. She has two children. She sells fruit and noodL. in the morning. Her family has a monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND. She is a group leader of 5 – member group loan offered by SEDA. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND to invest in her business.
 About the other borrower in her group:
Nhạn Thị Vương was born in 1976. (id: 010117050027). She has two children. She sells groceries. She needs 6.322.000 VND to buy more good to sell.
 Lệ Thị Nguyễn was born in 1968. (id: 010117050025). She has three children. She sells chicken in the market. She needs 5.450.000 VND to buy chicken.
 Hồng Thị Bùi was born in 1977. (id: 010117050030).  She has two children. She sells fish, noodL. in the market. She wants to borrow 5.450.000 VND to invest in small buseness.
 Thơm Thị Lê was born in 1971. (id: 010117050029 ). She has two children. She needs 4.578.000 VND to invest in her shop.

loans.use: to invest in her business

loans.name: Sasi

texts.en:
Sasi V.  is currently in the business of selling groundnut phaste and is requesting a loan to purchase tomatoes and onions to sell. 

 Sasi is 30 years old and is Married with a husband that is a teacher. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business in such a way that the realised profits from her loan will be used for buying cooking oil and maize flour for sale.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Batsuuri

texts.en: Batsuuri is 60 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Arkhangai province of Mongolia.  He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His youngest daughter recently graduated from college and his son will soon be getting married.  His middle child, a 23 year old daughter, is handicapped and stays at home with his wife.  Batsuuri sells water to the people of his town who live too far away from the town well. He owns two horses and a cart in which he makes his water deliveries. Batsuuri started this business in 2004 with only one horse. Since then, he has not only been able to purchase another horse, but he has been able to pay for his son and daughter’s college educations.  He would eventually like to own a well so that he can become even more profitable.  Batsuuri is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan in order to purchase the hay necessary for his horses to be able to survive the winter.

loans.use: to purchase the hay necessary for his horses to be able to survive the winter.

loans.name: Battumur

texts.en: C. Battumur is 50 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. His oldest daughter currently attends university, his youngest daughter is in kindergarten, and his teenage son attends a local secondary school. He operates a small wooden products production business in his town. Battumur started his wood products business in 2008 with capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD). By managing and conducting his business successfully, he has been able to achieve stable operations in a short time. Today, his working capital exceeds 600,000 tugrugs (~420 USD). He has used the success of his business to greatly improve his quality of life. For the future, Battumur hopes to improve the quality and increase the variety of wood products he produces. He hopes his future success will enable him to purchase a car that he will use in his business. He is requesting a 900,000 tugrug (~630 USD) loan to buy more wood for his business.

loans.use: to buy more wood for his business

loans.name: Anyawen

texts.en: Anyawen A. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase yeasts for brewing. Anyawen is 20 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more yeasts for brewing

loans.name: Horolgarav

texts.en:
Horolgarav is 43 years old and lives with her husband and 19-year-old son in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. Her son currently attends a local high school.

Horolgarav currently operates a meat retail business in her town with the help of her husband. She offers a variety of locally produced meats to her customers by selling at the local market. She started her meat business in 1996 with capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD). Her business has found success over the years and she has built a good reputation amongst her customers. Today, her working capital exceeds 2,500,000 tugrugs (~1750 USD).

For the future, Horolgarav hopes that she can become a meat wholesaler so she can sell on a larger scale. She also dreams of one day having her own meat trading shop. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat for her business

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia M. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to open a shop. Lucia is 35 years old and is married with a husband who is a chief. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Lucia M. hopes to be able to employ some workers in the charcoal-burning industry. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a shop

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 35-year-old married mother of two school-going children. She lives with her family in Gitare Embu. She is a member of a community-based women’s group affiliated to Runyenjes District Hospital.

Elizabeth owns a beauty salon which she started in 2006. She has applied for Kshs 40,000 to improve her business.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is the married mother of two children, one of whom has completed secondary school level and is waiting to join university. She lives with her family in Kigumo Runyenjes.

Lucy specializes in knitting sweaters as well as selling secondhand clothes. She has requested Kshs 50,000 to increase her stock of used clothes.

loans.use: To increase her stock of used clothes

loans.name: Oyunbat

texts.en:
Oyunbat is 52 years old and lives with his wife, his youngest daughter, and a grandchild in Bayankhongor province in Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. A father of four, Oyunbat has raised and supported all of his children through university; his youngest is currently a student.

Oyunbat operates a metal-crafting business in his town. He produces a variety of chimney and metal goods. Before starting his metal-craft business, he worked as a professional dancer for over twenty years. However, after injuring his back he took up work as a grocery retail trader from 1997 until 2007.

Oyunbat started his metal-craft business in 2007 and has grown it into a stable operation in a short time. For the future, he hopes to expand the business by hiring assistants as the work has become hard on his back. He also dreams of one day owning his own retail space.

Oyunbat is requesting a 600,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase tools and supplies for his metal-craft business.

loans.use: To purchase tools and supplies for his metal shop

loans.name: Inya

texts.en:
Inya G. is currently in the business of selling dried cassava flour and is requesting a loan to purchase and grind more cassava to sell.  

Inya is 35 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build cassava flour store for better stock.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase and grind more cassava to sell

loans.name: Martin

texts.en: Martin lives in Kigumo Runyenjes. He is a single man but is planning to get married soon. He owns a grocery stall where he sells vegetables such as tomatoes, onions, carrots, kale and potatoes. He buys stock directly from the local farmers. He needs Khs 30,000 to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Oyun-Erdene

texts.en:
Oyun-Erdene is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Oyun-Erdene owns and operates a meat retail trading business in her town. She started her business in 1997 with working capital of 80,000 tugrug (~55 USD). With the support of her family, the business has since grown to exceed working capital of 1,400,000 tugrug (~980 USD).

Oyun- Erdene has gained considerable business knowledge and skills in the twelve years of operating her business and hopes to be able to be able to not only expand and own operating space for the business, but to pass her knowledge and skills on to her children. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more meat and supplies so that she may increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase more meat and supplies

loans.name: Fredrick's Group

texts.en:
Fredrick is the married father of eight children, four of whom are still in school. He is a member of a group in Embu but owns a charcoal business in Ngong Kajiado.

Fredrick runs one of the largest charcoal stores in the area. He buys bags of charcoal, and supplies to retail outlets at Kshs 800 a bag, and is thus able to make a profit. He has applied for a loan of Kshs 50,000 to get more stock.

loans.use: To buy charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Tham's Group

texts.en:
Tham T. D. was born in 1962. (id: 010107070075). She lives in Xuan Trach village, Xuan Canh Commune, Dong Anh district. Her family includes her husband, mother-in-law, two sons, two daughters-in-law, and two grandsons. Her two sons are workers. Mrs Tham has a store at home. She sells many things for the people in her village. Everybody loves and believes her. She is a group leader. This time, Mrs Tham wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND to buy goods to resell in her shop.
 
About the other borrowers in her group:
N. T. N. was born in 1957. (id: 010107070073). She sells groceries at home. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to invest in her general store.
Tuyet T. D. was born in 1967. (id: 010107070072). She has two children. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to buy feed for her pigs.

loans.use: to buy goods for her shop.

loans.name: Tsendbazar

texts.en:
Tsendbazar is 34 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest daughter currently attends university and his younger two sons are high school students.

Tsendbazar operates a small café in his town with the help of his wife. The two rent space in a building where they produce quality meals for their customers. Tsendbazar started his café in 2007 with capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~150 USD). Due to his hard work, he has found success in a short time and, today, his working capital exceeds 600,000 tugrugs (~450 USD).

For the future, Tsendbazar hopes to move from his rented space and own his own café. He needs to expand so that he can better serve all of his customers. He is requesting a 500,000 tugrug loan in order to buy more materials and produce in order to cook satisfying meals for his customers.

loans.use: To purchase more food products for his café

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is aged 32 years. She is a widow and is the mother of two school-going children. She lives in Gitare Runyenjes.

Mary owns a retail shop which she started in 2000. She sells essentials items mostly used in the community such as sugar, flour, rice, and kerosene.  She has applied for Kshs 30,000 to improve her business.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a 35-year-old married mother of four children. She lives in Kigumo Runyenjes.

Florence currently sells secondhand and new clothes. She gets her stock in Nairobi where there is a variety of stock currently in the market. She needs Kshs 20,000 to get more stock.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Dori

texts.en:
Dori E. is currently in the business of selling charcoal  and is requesting a loan to build charcoal store .  Dori is 29 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 2 children and her children go to school. 

 With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land, build and rent it out.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: build charcoal store

loans.name: Davaadolgor

texts.en:
D. Davaadolgor is 39 years old and lives with her husband in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She currently operates a clothing retail business with her husband at a shop in her town. For her business, Davaadolgor must travel to the Chinese border city of Erlian to purchase her goods and transport them back to her shop.

Davaadolgor started her clothing business in 1996 by selling her products at the local market. She quickly found success and expanded her business. Davaadolgor and her husband are very hardworking people and have used their business to greatly improve their quality of life. Her business has developed a positive reputation throughout the community and has achieved stable operations. Today, Davaadolgor's working capital exceeds 4,500,000 tugrugs (~3180 USD).

For the future, Davaadolgor hopes to expand her business further by purchasing a wider variety of clothing items to sell. She is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more clothing items for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing items for her shop

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en: Johnson is the 45-year-old father of two school-going children. He lives in Runyenjes where he also runs a boutique. He deals in both ladies and gents wares. He has applied for Kshs 50,000 to improve his business.

loans.use: To use for business improvement

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is the 50-year-old father of five school-going children. He owns a retail shop in Runyenjes and also work as a private surveyor. He has applied for Kshs 50,000 to improve his business by purchasing more stock.

loans.use: To improve his business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en:
C. Lhagvasuren is 34 years old and lives with her father and 8 year-old daughter in Arkhhangai province in central Mongolia. She lives together with her family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter attends a local secondary school while her father stays home during the day.

Lhagvasuren operates a meat retail business at the local market in her town. Her business is very important to her as it is the only source of income for her family. Lhagvasuren started her meat business in 2005 with capital of about 100,000 tugrugs (~70 USD). Since then, she has established herself amongst her customers as being very reliable and trustworthy and her business has reaped the benefits. Today, after years of effectively managing her business' growth, her working capital exceeds 1,000,000 tugrugs (~700 USD).

For the future, Lhagvasuren hopes to grow her business further in the hope of owning her own stall at a large store. She is also focused on providing a quality life for her family, most importantly her daughter's education. She hopes that her daughter will one day become well educated and contribute to the future development of Mongolia. Lhagvasuren is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) loan to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat for her business

loans.name: Kaku

texts.en:
Kaku L. is 20 years old and married to a businessman. She has two school-going children. Kaku sells beer and cooking oil from home and is requesting a loan to open a bar at the nearby market. With the extra profits from her loan, Kaku hopes to build a store for selling foodstuffs such as rice, beans, etc.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar at the nearby market

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a hardworking young entrepreneur. She is 26 years old and a married mother of two children. Agnes started her retail business in 2002. It has done well thanks to her first loan that helped her buy stock in bulk. She now requires 40,000 KES to enable her to purchase more supplies.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
P. Oyun is 57 years old and lives with her husband and 20-year-old son in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. The family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Oyun's son is currently attending university. 

Oyun operates a clothing business in her town. She buys imported clothes from China, which she transports back home for sale at the local market. Oyun started her clothing business in 2002 with capital of 100,000 MNT. Since then, she has increased her sales and has grown her business' reputation amongst her customers and competitors. Today, her working capital exceeds 800,000 MNT. She attributes her success to her good managerial and accounting skills, and is known by her customers for her polite nature.

In the future, Oyun hopes to further expand her product line to include a wider variety of clothes in an effort to attract new customers. She is requesting a 200,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothing items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing items for her business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a hardworking young entrepreneur. She is 26 years old and a married mother of two children. Agnes started her retail business in 2002. It has done well thanks to her first loan that helped her buy stock in bulk. She now requires 40,000 KES to enable her to purchase more supplies.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies

loans.name: Tserensodnom

texts.en:
Tserensodnom is 39 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Arhangai province in central Mongolia.  He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two children both attend high school and his wife is a teacher. 

Tserensodnom operates a retail dairy business. He purchases products from the nearby Tuvshruuleh sum, a small provincial area, and delivers them either to the Khasu market in Arhangai or the central market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Tserensodnom started his dairy business in 2006 with capital of 320,000 MNT. He has managed his business so well that not only has his capital grown to 1,200,000 MNT, but he has also managed to purchase a new car as well. Tserensodnom’s goal is to one day own a milk processing factory, and he knows that with hard work and dedication that goal is possible. He is requesting a 1,100,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more dairy supplies for his growing business.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy supplies

loans.name: Cerina

texts.en:
Cerina G. is 30 years old and married to a teacher. She has three school-aged children. Cerina is currently in the business of selling tea, bread, paste and tomatoes, and is requesting a loan to purchase cooking oil and onions to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees and purchase food for home consumption.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil and onions to sell

loans.name: Kibiimba Group

texts.en:
Alice B. is the president of Kibiimba Group. She leads the women of the group by using innovative ideas for fighting poverty. She is forty-seven years old and single. She is a hardworking business woman who is blessed with six children, one of whom is in school. She is also looking after three dependents, two of whom are also in school.

Alice deals mostly with charcoal although she also sells firewood and milk. She has been operating these businesses for over twenty years. She is using the loan to purchase more inventory including charcoal, firewood, and milk to improve her business and generate more profits. She is always trying hard to encourage her group members to be successful. Her future hope is to construct a house for her children where they can at least feel comfortable.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory including charcoal, firewood, and milk

loans.name: Kibiimba Talipa Night Group

texts.en: T. Night has been chosen and trusted by her group members to be the group's cashier. She is 34 years old and married with three school-aged children. She also looks after two dependents, who are also in school. For the last ten years T. Night has had a retail business. She is using her loan to purchase retail items such as cooking oil, soap, salt, matchboxes, paraffin, sugar, etc. to improve the stock her business holds. T. Night, along with the rest of her group, is looking forward to prospering through her loan. Her future hope is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase items such as cooking oil, soap, salt, matchboxes, paraffin, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Gnanyome

texts.fr: Cette jeune dame habite l’un des quartiers périphériques de Lomé peuplé d’habitants : le quartier Minamadou à Agoè. Elle a appris la coiffure. Elle exerce ce métier depuis 2006 et cette activité lui permet non seulement de se prendre en charge mais aussi de subvenir aux besoins scolaires des ses petits frères. Elle est bien connue dans son quartier et coiffe ses clientes dans la perfection. Elle profite aussi de cette occasion pour vendre des mèches ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour renouveler son stock de mèches en baisse en ce moment. Avec l’argent du prêt, elle pourra s’acheter 100 mèches Nina et 100 mèches Curly. Cette femme n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Elle n’a aucune crainte de rembourser son prêt dans les délais en vigueur.

loans.use: Achat de mèches

loans.name: Ganiya

texts.fr: Cette dame s’est spécialisée dans la vente de glacières de différentes dimensions. Elle habite le quartier d'Agoè-Dèmakpoe à Lomé. C’est une revendeuse ambulante ; elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2006 à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins de base. Actuellement elle veut louer une place dans le marché d’Agoè à Lomé pour élargir son commerce. Elle a beaucoup d’ambitions et voudrait plus tard se rendre en Côte d’Ivoire  pour pouvoir vendre en gros. Actuellement son stock est presque épuisé ; c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 60 glacières, petit et grand format. Elle compte sur sa meilleure connaissance de son marché pour vite rembourser son crédit. Elle est célibataire et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge.
texts.en:
This is a lady who became specialized in selling insulated containers of various sizes. She lives in the Agoè-Dèmakpoe district in Lomé. She is a door-to-door retailer; she started this business in 2006 in Lomé. It enables her to cover her basic expenses. Currently, she wants to lease a spot at the Agoè marketplace in Lomé in order to expand her commerce. She has many ambitions and would like to go to Cote d’Ivoire later on, so as to sell in bulk. Right now, her stock is almost exhausted; for this reason, she’s requesting a WAGES loan to buy 60 insulated containers, small and large. She is counting on her better knowledge of the market to repay her loan quickly. She is unmarried and has no children at all to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy insulated containers

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en: B. Florence is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a business lady with a drug shop that she has been running for a long time. She is a single mother of 5 children with 1 at the university while the others are in secondary and primary schools. Before the drug shop, Florence was a salary earner until she used her little savings plus the help of a loan to start up her own business. At the moment out of her 7 year old business, she makes 80,000/= as profits and this helps her in looking after her children plus paying their school fees. Florence has a dream of becoming a whole sale supplier of drugs in her locality and also build rental houses for her children. Her secret to success is having quality drugs that are not expired and she would need a loan to help add capital in business so that she can work on her customers on time.

loans.use: Buying more drugs for business expansion.

loans.name: Kitere Abakyara Tukwatanisa Angellica Rusoki Group

texts.en: Angellica R. is the President of Kitere Abakyara Tukwatanisa group. She is forty-eight years old business woman and married with nine children of whom five are going to school and she is more so managing to take care of four dependents. She deals with poultry business, so far ten years operating the business. She is using the loan to purchase chicken, drugs, feeds, etc for her poultry. She hopes of boosting her business. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and more so a cow

loans.use: To purchase chicken, drugs, feeds, etc for her poultry. She hopes of boosting her business.

loans.name: Afi Dawui

texts.fr: Afi est une femme qui s’est lancée dans le commerce du bois de chauffe depuis 2002. Elle habite le quartier d’Agoe-Logopé à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet de se prendre en charge et de subvenir aux besoins universitaires de sa petite sœur. Elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays, plus précisément à Kpalimé, localité située à des dizaines de kilomètre de Lomé. Elle est bien connue dans son quartier comme étant spécialisée dans la vente de bois de chauffe de meilleure qualité. Actuellement elle approvisionne certains petits restaurants et les maquis de la capitale. Elle a besoin de lancer en ce moment une nouvelle commande ; c’est pourquoi elle compte beaucoup sur un crédit de WAGES  pour acheter un taxi bagage de bois de chauffage. Le reste du prêt servira à couvrir ses frais de transport vers l’intérieur du pays. Cette femme n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge.
texts.en:
Afi is a woman who started a business involving firewood in 2002. She lives in the Agoe-Logopé district in Lomé. This business enables her to support herself and to provide for her younger sister attending university. Afi stocks up in the country’s interior, in Kpalimé to be exact; it’s a town located dozens of kilometers from Lomé. She is also well-known in her area, since she is specialized in selling better-quality firewood. Currently, she supplies certain small restaurants and eateries of the capital. At present, she needs to start a new supply order; this is why she is counting a lot on a WAGES loan in order to buy a luggage-taxi of firewood. The rest of the loan will be used to cover the costs of transport to the country’s interior. This woman is not married and has no children at all to support.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: Amina

texts.fr: Madame Amina est une femme qui habite le quartier d’Agoe Zongo à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente des produits d’alimentation générale. Elle a ouvert sa boutique en 2006 et cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa contribution financière dans le foyer. Sa boutique est très connue des gens de son quartier qui la visitent à cause du bon accueil qu’elle a toujours su réserver à ses clients. Elle vend aussi bien en gros qu’en détail. Actuellement elle a un besoin pressant de renouveler son stock ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 03 cartons de lait, 05 cartons de savons, 07 boîtes de conserves de tomates, 06 bidons d’huiles, 12 cartons de pâtes alimentaires.

loans.use: Achat de lait, de tomates, de savons et de pâtes alimentaires

loans.name: Kitere Abakyara Tukwatanisa Sekabira Safina Group

texts.en: S. Safina is an encouraging business woman of forty years old, married with three children schooling and looking after two dependents of which one is going to school. She deals with firewood business and used clothes. She is using the loan to purchase stock of firewood and used clothes for sale. In her group they are encouraging one another to work and S. Safinas’ future hope is to expand on her business.

loans.use: To purchase stock of firewood and used clothes for sale.

loans.name: Maguelewa

texts.fr: Cette femme habite le quartier d’Agoè Adjougba à Lomé. Elle est mariée à un militaire et le couple a 02 enfants. Elle a appris la coiffure ; malheureusement, elle n’a pas pu trouver les moyens pour ouvrir son atelier de coiffure. C’est pour cette raison qu’en 2004, elle a pris la ferme décision de se lancer dans la vente de charbon de bois pour aider financièrement son mari. Grâce à ce choix, ils arrivent ensemble à assurer l’éducation scolaire de leurs enfants. Avec ce nouveau commerce, elle arrive à vendre des sacs entiers dans la semaine ; à présent elle est bien connue de beaucoup de gens. Pour renouveler  son stock en état d’épuisement, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 09 sacs de charbon de bois ; le prêt lui servira également de s’approvisionner à Atakpamé, une localité située à des dizaines de kilomètres de Lomé.

loans.use: Achat de sacs de charbon de bois

loans.name: Malita

texts.fr: Cette femme est spécialisée dans la vente d’une bouillie très appréciée de la population dénommée « akassa » ; c’est une bouillie faite avec de la farine de maïs fermentée. Elle s’est lancée dans ce commerce en 1995 parce que les revenus financiers de son mari électricien ferrailleur, n’arrivent plus à couvrir tous les besoins du foyer. Le couple a 03 enfants, c’est pourquoi cette dame veut compléter les revenus de son mari pour assurer l’éducation scolaire de leurs enfants. Elle vend sa bouillie dans le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé et dispose de beaucoup de clients. Les gens apprécient  sa bouillie et le bon accueil qu’elle a toujours eu à les réserver. Actuellement elle a besoin de disposer des stocks en provision ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 05 sacs de maïs, 01 sac de riz et du bois de chauffage.
texts.en:
This is a woman who is specialized in selling a much appreciated porridge called akassa, which is made from fermented cornmeal. She started her business in 1995 because her husband’s income from being a scrap metal merchant and electrician was no longer managing to cover all household expenses. The couple has three children. This is why this lady wants to round out her husband’s income, so as to ensure that their children are educated. She sells her porridge in the Agoè district in Lomé and has many customers. People appreciate her porridge and the nice welcome she always reserves for them. Currently, she needs supplies. For this reason, she’s requesting a WAGES loan to buy 5 sacks of corn, 1 sack of rice, and some firewood.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn, sugar, and firewood

loans.name: May's Group

texts.en:
N. May is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a 44-year-old widow who has two children, both of whom are at university. She also takes care of three dependents.

May has a poultry farm and a market stall from where she sells most of her birds in Namengo. She has been in this business for three years and is successful because of her experience and hard work. At the moment, she is able to make 50,000 UGX as her weekly profit. However, she is faced with the problem of limited capital and her need of expensive medicines for her chickens at the poultry farm. She needs a loan to increase her working capital in order to buy more chicks, feed, medicines and so on.

May would like to see an increase in the quantity of birds at her farm, and hopes that one day she is able to own a shop building for rent. She also hopes to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To buy chicks, feeds and medicines for her poultry farm

loans.name: Fatumah's Group

texts.en:
Fatumah is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a determined, hard-working lady with a three-year-old brewing business that she runs from her home. She brews waragi (distilled from bananas, cassava, millet or sugar cane), tonto (green bananas and roasted sorghum) and malwa (millet). She sells her brews mostly to bar owners but also to customers who prefer to take them home. She uses her savings and profits to cover most of her and her children’s needs.

Since she is wholly in charge of paying her children’s school fees, Fatumah is requesting a loan to help pay for these particular costs. She will use her profits from her successful brewing business to pay back her loan.

loans.use: To pay for her children's school fees

loans.name: Nyabusozi Twekambe Kahibire Balibina Group

texts.en: K. Balibina is a business woman of fifty years old, single parent of five children and looking after four siblings of which three are going to school. She has been a farmer for over twenty years. She is using the loan to maintain the plantations by purchasing fertilizers, pay wages to the people helping her in the plantation etc. she is a hardworking and active woman. Her dream is to educate her children

loans.use: To maintain the plantations by purchasing fertilizers, pay wages to the people helping her in the plantation etc.

loans.name: Bukwali Bwera Kabahweza Consolata Group

texts.en: K. Consolata is the president of Bukwali-Bwera group; she is forty-four years old. She is married with five children schooling and looking after one dependent. She has been dealing with transportation that is small motorcycle for boda business since the year 2008. She wants to add on her capital to purchase a B. motorcycle (bajaj) for good work and more so people prefer B. motorcycles than the small ones. She is just fine hoping for B. success in future. She is encouraging and hardworking; her dream is to purchase a car for the taxi work that is for daily income.

loans.use: To purchase a big motorcycle (bajaj) for good work and more so people prefer big motorcycles than the small ones.

loans.name: Resty's Group

texts.en: N. Resty is the leader of her group in Lugazi. She is a hard working and devoted lady with a retail shop business that she has had for 5 years. She is a mother of 5 children who are all in school as she cares for 2 dependants. She opened up her shop using savings from agriculture and only joined her lending group to increase on the capital. Resty has a dream of expanding her shop to include more products that will bring in more income as well as buying a commercial plot in the middle of her trading centre. She currently needs a loan to help with restocking her retail shop with more goods for increased profitability.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods.

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en: O. John is a fisherman operating from Busaana landing site. He is 50 years old and married with 4 children aged between 17 – 9 years as he takes care of other orphans. John has been a fisherman all his adult life and his main business challenge is the seasonality of fish from the source. However, he is able to make 100,000/= as profits a week and this enables him to make needs available to her family. He strives to become a supplier of fish country wide so that he can be able to make more profits as well as be able to pay school fees for his children. He needs to add more capital to his business by employing more men to help in his fishing business since this ensures a steady supply of fish to his customers.

loans.use: Employing manpower to help in his fishing business for increased catch.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 32 years old. She is married and has four children between the ages of 4 and 13. All of her children go to school. Mary rents a one room house where she lives with four people. The house has electricity but no piped water. Mary takes care of additional family members, and the family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Mary sells secondhand clothes in Ndeeba Market. She works seven days a week and receives 30 customers a day. She doesn’t incur extra transport costs because she buys from her place of work. The major challenges she faces include paying for monthly market dues and medication, feeding her family, and the increasing price of clothes. Besides the clothing business, she also sells fruits.

Mary has been in this business for 9 years and with MCDT for three years. She is servicing her ninth loan with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of clothes. Mary is aspiring to grow her business and own a permanent business structure and home.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand clothes

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en: Hadjah is a 48 year married with 7 children aged between 6 and 17 years.All her children go to school. Hadjah resides and owns a two roomed house where she staying with nine people. There is electricity and no piped water at home. Hadjah takes care of additional family members  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  She receives 20 customers a day. Hadjah owns a retail shop selling home products goods and other soft drinks in Makerere and sells to all categories of people.  She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  The major challenges she faces in her business are transportation and medication and feeding the family. Hadjah has been with MCDT for 8 years servicing her sixteenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of soda soap salt sugar and other merchandise Hadjah is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business structure and also build a house from the available profits

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her reatil shop

loans.name: Sophia Naula’S Group

texts.en: Sophia is a 35 year married with 4 children aged between 3 and 14 years.All her children go to school. Sophia resides and rents a two roomed house where she staying with ten people. There is electricity and no piped water at home. Sophia takes care of four additional family members  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  She receives 20 customers a day. Sophia owns a restaurant selling food and soft drinks in Makerere and sells to all categories of people.  She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  The major challenges she faces in her business are rent, medication, feeding the family and increasing food prices. Sophia has been in this business for 8 years and with MCDT for five years servicing her sixteenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of soda and stock more food stuffs Sophia is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business structure and also build a house from the available profits

loans.use: To buy more crates of soda and other food stuffs

loans.name: Rebecca Nassuna Group

texts.en:
Rebecca is 32 years old and married with four children between the ages of two and fifteen years, three of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Rebecca rents a two-room house with electricity but no piped water in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. Seven other people live in this house. Her family eats three meals a day.

Rebecca sells spare parts for motorcycles seven days a week in Bwaise, south of Kampala. She receives an average of five customers a day. The major financial challenges she faces are transportation to work and shopping, school fees and rent.

Rebbecca has been with MCDT (Micro Credit for Development and Transformation) for five years with the same group mates and is paying off her tenth loan. She is requesting this loan to buy more spare parts for her shop. Rebecca aspires to see her business grow bigger so she may own her own shop and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: Semugenya's Group

texts.en:
Semugenya J. is a hardworking woman with a retail shop in Lweru trading centre. She is 45 years old and married. She is responsible for twelve children between the ages of four and 24 years, some her own and some, orphans. 

Semugenya used to be a farmer but was affected by the drop in price of produce and so changed to retail sales. From her shop she makes 200,000 UGX in profits, mostly attributable to the use of her loan and the quality of her products. 

At the moment, Semugenya is requesting a loan to restock her shop with more goods and to pay for part of her children’s school fees. Semugenya dreams of becoming a wholesaler as well as educating her children to the highest level.

loans.use: To restock her shop with more products

loans.name: Juan Pedro

texts.es: Juan Pedro es soltero, tiene 2 hijos los cuales estudian, labora como conductor de taxi desde hace 9 años, pero ahora conduce su propio taxi, pues con el apoyo de su compañera de vida han logrado obtener su propio vehiculo y consesion del taxi, adicionalmente se dedica junto a su compañera de vida a la venta de electrodomesticos de contado y al credito con clientes seleccionados, por lo que esta solicitando refinanciamiento de su 3er credito para comprar mercaderia y abastecer del producto a varios clientes que les hicieron pedido de los artefactos, ya que en este momento no cuentan con el suficiente capital para comparlo todo, expresa que las politicas de credito de AFODENIC son muy buenas y por eso le gusta trabajar con esta financiera.
texts.en:
Juan Pedro is single, and he has two children who go to school. He has worked as a taxi drive for nine years. Now he drives his own taxi. With support from his life partner he has been able to get his own vehicle and taxi concession. Also, he and his life partner sell domestic appliances for cash and for credit to their regular customers. He is asking for his third loan to buy merchandise and stock the various devices that their customers have ordered. They do not have sufficient money to buy everything. He says that the AFODENIC’s loan policies are very good, and that is why he likes to work with this financing institution.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for his business

loans.name: Leydie Wasty

texts.fr: Leydie est une dame qui a appris la couture ; elle avait ouvert un atelier de couture et disposait même des apprenties couturières. Malheureusement, elle avait fermé son atelier parce qu’elle n’avait pas assez de clients, alors qu’elle devrait régler les frais de location de son atelier. C’est pour cette raison qu’elle s’est lancée en 2004 dans la vente de certaines boissons alcoolisées, de pâtes alimentaires, de lait, d’eau minérale. Avec cette nouvelle activité, elle arrive à subvenir à ses propres besoins ; elle exerce ce commerce dans le quartier d’Agoè Réserve à Lomé, où elle est très connue de beaucoup de personnes. Elle a besoin en ce moment de renouveler son stock ; c’est pour cela qu’elle voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 bouteilles de la boisson Pastis, 10 bouteilles de Golden Dry, 20 boîtes du vin Bonita, 01 carton du lait en conserve, 01 boîte de tomates et une boîte de pâte alimentaire spaghetti. Cette dame n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge.

loans.use: Achat de boissons alcoolisées, de tomates, de lait, de pâte alimentaire

loans.name: Akouwah

texts.fr: Mme Akouwah est mariée à un Directeur  de société à Lomé ; le couple a un enfant. Grâce à l’aide de son mari, cette dame a ouvert un restaurant  dans le quartier d’Agoè FIR à Lomé. Le restaurant est ouvert en 2007 et est très visité par des militaires, des joueurs de golf et bien d’autres visiteurs. C’est un restaurant qui se situe à quelques mètres d’un terrain de Golf Club très fréquenté par les touristes étrangers. C’est dire que c’est un restaurant de renom, très connu et très apprécié. Actuellement elle a besoin de constituer un nouveau stock ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 casiers de la boisson alcoolisée Guiness, 10 casiers de la boisson alcoolisée Lager, 10 casiers de sucreries, 05 cartons de tomates, 10 cartons de Spaghetti, 05 sacs de riz, des carottes et des piments.
texts.en:
Ms. Akouwah is married to a manager of a private company in Lomé; the couple has one child. Thanks to her husband’s help, this lady opened a restaurant in the Agoè FIR district in Lomé. The restaurant opened in 2007 and is patronized very much by soldiers, golfers, and many other visitors. It’s located a few meters from a Golf Club course that is popular with foreign tourists. That is to say, it’s a widely-recognized restaurant, renowned, and much appreciated. At present, she needs to establish a new inventory. For this reason, she’s requesting a WAGES loan to buy 10 cases of the alcoholic drink Guiness, 10 cases of the alcoholic drink Lager, 10 cases of soft drinks, 5 boxes of tomatoes, 10 boxes of spaghetti, 5 sacks of rice, and some carrots and chili peppers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy case of drinks, boxes of tomatoes, spaghetti, sacks of rice

loans.name: Maria Soledad

texts.es: Maria Soledad L. S. tiene 40 años. Es una Señora muy responsable y trabajadora ella tiene un gran espíritu emprendedor. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta de roa usada. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio, sale todos los días de sol a sol a buscar nuevos clientes y a promocionar su ropa, a pesar de las dificultades que atravesó como fue el problema de su artritis ya que no podía caminar grandes distancias, pero esto era un sacrificio que ella tenía que hacer por sus 3 hijos. Ella solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de camisetas, pantalones, faldas y ropa para niños por lo que es la más solicitada por sus clientes. Su deseo es que sus hijos logren finalizar sus estudios para que sean personas de bien y con un buen futuro.
texts.en:
Maria Soledad L. S. is 40. She is a very responsible, hard-working woman with a great entrepreneurial spirit. She sells used clothes. She has been doing this for over five years. She leaves everyday from sunup to sundown looking for new customers and promoting her clothes. She does this in spite of difficulties she has encountered, like her arthritis and not being able to walk long distances. This was the sacrifice she had to make for her three children. She is asking for this loan for working capital to buy shirts, pants, skirts, and children’s clothes, which are the items her customers ask for the most. Her wish is that her children finish their education and that they become successful people with a good future.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is a 40 year widow with four children aged between 10 and16 years. All her children go to school.  Ruth resides and stays in a one roomed rented house where she staying with five people. There is no electricity but has piped water at home.  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area and works seven days a week.  She serves 30 customers a day.  She incurs extra transport to and from shopping in Owino market.  The major challenges she faces in her business are transport costs and seasonality and when the bananas are scarce for twelve years and with MCDT for five years servicing her fifteenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to increase more bunches of bananas.  Ruth is aspiring to see her business grow bigger to start going to farmers directly.

loans.use: To buy more bananas

loans.name: Kodjo Dodji

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente de cartes de recharge téléphoniques. Il a débuté cette activité depuis 2007 dans le quartier d’Agoè Démakpoè à Lomé. Il est célibataire et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Ce commerce lui permet de se prendre en charge et de subvenir à ses besoins. Il a pu négocier avec le propriétaire d’un bar dans le quartier, ce qui lui a permis de disposer d’un petit bureau de vente à l’intérieur. C’est un bar qui est très fréquenté, et il en profite pour vendre des cartes de recharge Togocel. Actuellement il a besoin de renouveler son stock qui s’épuise ; c’est pour cette raison qu’il voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 25 cartes de recharges de 4500Fcfa, 25 cartes de recharges de 2000Fcfa, 120 cartes de recharge de 1000Fcfa et 389 cartes de recharges de 450Fcfa.
texts.en:
This young man has an income-generating business selling mobile phone recharge cards. He started this business in 2007 in the Agoè Démakpoè district in Lomé. He is unmarried and has no children at all to support. This business enables him to be self-reliant and to provide for himself. He was able to negotiate with an area bar owner to have a sale office available inside the bar. This bar is popular, and he takes advantage of it to sell Togocel recharge cards. At present, he needs to renew his stock, which is running out. For this reason, he would like to obtain a WAGES loan to buy 25 recharge cards worth 4,500 francs CFA each, 25 cards worth 2,000 f each, 120 cards worth 1,000 f each, and 389 cards worth 450 f each.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy phone cards to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 48 and married with two children ages 10 and 18. Both her children go to school. Betty rents a two roomed house where she is staying with five people. Also, Betty takes care of additional family members The family gets three meals a day. There is electricity but no piped water at her home.

Betty resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week and receives 15 customers a day. Betty sells clothes to women only. She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping. The major challenges she faces in her business are the rainy season and monthly market dues.

Betty has been with MCDT for seven years and is servicing her eighteenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothing. Betty aspires to seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business structure; she now works from an open-air place.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes

loans.name: Affi

texts.fr: Cette dame s’est spécialisée dans la vente d’une bouillie très appréciée de la population dénommée « akloui zogbon ». C’est une bouillie faite à base de  farine de maïs fermenté.  Elle a débuté cette activité depuis 1998 dans le quartier d’Agoè Démakpoè à Lomé. Cette activité lui permet de se prendre en charge et de subvenir à ses besoins. Elle n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Son commerce se situe au bord d’une rue très fréquentée ce qui fait qu’elle réalise de bonnes affaires. Elle se lève très tôt le matin et bien avant la fin de la matinée, elle finit de tout vendre. Elle a besoin en ce moment de renouveler son stock ; c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 05 sacs de maïs, 03 sacs de sucre et du bois de chauffage. Elle compte rembourser ce crédit dans les délais exigés.

loans.use: Achat de sacs de maïs, de sucre, de bois de chauffage

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a 49 year married with five children aged between 13 and 25 years.Three of her children go to school.  Sarah resides and owns a five roomed house where she staying with eight people. There is electricity and no piped water at home. Sarah takes care of additional family members  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  She receives 15 customers a day.  Sarah sells charcoal in Katanga and besides the charcoal stall she also practices outside catering.  She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  The major challenges she faces in her business are transportation and rising food prices.  Sarah has been with MCDT for five years servicing her tenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal and stock enough food stuffs which are not perishable..  Sarah is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owing a permanent business structure as of now works from an open place.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal and other food stuffs

loans.name: Moutawakilou

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme s’est spécialisé dans vente d’huile à moteur dans le quartier d’Agoè Zongo à Lomé ; il a débuté cette activité depuis 1999 et ce commerce lui permet surtout de se prendre en charge et de subvenir à ses besoins. Il se rend parfois au Nigéria pour s’approvisionner en huile à moteur mais aussi au Bénin le pays voisin. Son commerce se situe en bordure d’un rue très fréquentée par les taxis motos, ce qui fait qu’il dispose de beaucoup de clients. Actuellement il a besoin de renouveler son stock ; c’est pour cette raison qu’il voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 250 litres d’huile à moteur. Il est célibataire et sans enfant.
texts.en:
This is a young man who became specialized in selling motor oil in the Agoè Zongo district in Lomé; he started this business in 1999, and it enables him in particular to be self-reliant and to provide for himself. He sometimes goes to Nigeria to stock up on motor oil but also to Benin, the neighboring country. His business is located on a roadside bustling with moto taxis, which means he has many customers. At present, he needs to renew his stock. For this reason, he would like to obtain a WAGES loan to buy 250 liters of motor oil. He is unmarried and has no children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy motor oil

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary sells fries, chapatis and samosas. She lives and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She gets 40 customers a day. Mary incurs transport costs to and from her suppliers. Mary has been in this business for 20 years. The major challenges she faces are monthly market dues, medication costs, feeding the family and increasing prices of wheat flour and cooking oil.

Mary is a 50 year single woman with four children between the ages of 20 and 36 years. Mary also takes care of additional family members. Only one of her children goes to school. Mary owns a four-roomed house where she lives with five people. There is electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Mary has been with MCDT for 11 years, now servicing her 20th loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar. Mary hopes to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business structure.

loans.use: To buy wheat and cooking oil

loans.name: Norah

texts.en: Norah is a 57 year widowed with 6 children aged between 20 and 36 years.Only two of her children goes to school. Norah resides and owns a ten roomed house where she staying with ten people. There is electricity and no piped water at home.  Norah takes care of additional family members  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  She receives 30 customers a day. Norah sells yellow bananas in Nakawa.  She doesn’t incur extra transport cost to and from shopping.as she buys from her place of work.  The major challenges she faces in her business are monthly market dues, medication, feeding the family and increasing prices of bananas. Besides this bananas business she also sells charcoal. Norah has been in this business for 20 years and with MCDT for eleven years servicing her twentieth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more yellow banana clusters. Norah is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permant business structure.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas and charcoal

loans.name: Fatuma Nassanga’S Group

texts.en:
Fatuma owns a stall selling plastics. She lives and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She gets 20 customers a day. Fatuma incurs transport costs to and from her suppliers. The major challenges she faces are monthly market dues, medication costs, feeding her family and rising plastic prices. She has been in this business for 6 years.

Fatuma is a 48-year-old married woman with five children between the ages of 10 and 17 years. She also takes care of additional family members. All her children go to school. Fatuma owns a three-roomed house where she lives with six people. There is electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets three meals a day.

Fatuma has been with MCDT for ten years, now servicing her 20th loan working with the same group mate. She wants to use this loan to buy more plastics. Fatuma is hoping to see her business grow bigger. She wants to own a permanent business structure and to open up another stall.

loans.use: To buy more plastics for resale

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a 37 year married with seven children aged between 3 and 17 years.All of her children goes to school. Mary resides and rents one roomed house where she staying with four people. There is electricity and no piped water at home.  Mary takes care of additional family members  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  She receives 30 customers a day. Mary sells second hand clothes in Ndeeba Market.  She doesn’t incur extra transport cost to and from shopping.as she buys from her place of work.  The major challenges she faces in her business are monthly market dues, medication, feeding the family and increasing prices of clothes. Besides this clothing business she also sells fruits. Mary has been in this business for 9 years and with MCDT for three years servicing her ninth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of clothes Mary is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business structure and home.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Labirou

texts.fr: Ce jeune homme est un tapissier qui a débuté cette activité au cours de cette année ; son atelier est localisé dans le quartier d’Agoè Atsanoé à Lomé. Le nom de son atelier est « La Classe », par référence au travail bien fait qu’il a déjà fourni à une dizaine de clients. Il s’approvisionne au Ghana pour les mousses et tissus de qualité, afin de pouvoir se différencier de ses concurrents. Il compte faire de la publicité dans l’avenir afin de gagner de nouveaux marchés. Il prévoit même accueillir des apprentis tapissiers. Pour disposer de nouveaux stocks, il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 134 mousses, mais aussi des tissus, de la colle, des fils et divers articles de nécessité. Il est célibataire et sans enfant.

loans.use: Achat de mousses, de tissus, de colle, de fils à coudre

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en: Aziza is a 34 year married with 7 children aged between 3 and 17 years.All her children go to school. Aziza resides and owns a three roomed house where she staying with six people. There is electricity and no piped water at home. Aziza takes care of additional family members  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  She receives 20 customers a day. Aziza owns a stall of snacks and charcoal and incurs transport costs to and from shopping.  The major challenges she faces in her business are monthly market dues, medication, feeding the family and increasing food prices. Aziza has been in this business for 6 years and with MCDT for eight years servicing her sixteenth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more charcoal and stock more vegetables and fruits. Aziza is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business structure and open up another stall .

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Maria Jose

texts.es: La señora Maria José T., ella tiene 23 años de edad, es soltera y no tiene hijos. Maria tiene 7 años de dedicarse a la compra-venta de zapatos, uniformes, cosméticos y artículos variados. Cabe señalarse, ella dio inicio a este negocio debido a la necesidad de auto mantenerse económicamente, debido a la situación actual del país. Ya que siempre le ha gustado ser una persona muy independiente ya que es una joven capaz de lograr sus metas además a ella le gustaría seguir estudiando y con sus propios esfuerzos piensa que podrá hacerlo. El crédito será invertido en la compra de zapatos y uniformes escolares para aprovechar las ventas de este mes de septiembre, ya que ahorita tiene bastantes pedidos. Ella tiene un sueño de llegar a tener una tienda, en la cual pueda ser un negocio bien establecido en el que pueda vender todo lo relacionado con vestuario y cosméticos
texts.en:
Señora Maria José T. is 23 years old, single, and does not have children. For 7 years she has sold shoes, uniforms, cosmetics and other items. It should be noted that she started this business due to the necessity of maintaining herself economically, given the current situation in the country. She has always enjoyed being an independent person, since she is a young person who is capable of achieving her goals. In addition, she would like to continue her studies, and through her own efforts she thinks that she will be able to do this. This loan will be invested in the purchase of shoes and school uniforms to take advantage of the sales in this month of September given that now she has enough orders to fill. She has a dream of eventually having a store, which could become a well-established business in which she could sell everything related to clothing and cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Jose Marcial

texts.es:
el señor Jose Marcial García tiene 63 años de edad,  el esta separado de su esposa y de el depende una hija que esta en la escuela, Jose vive en la aldea El Coyolito.
Jose se dedica al negocio de los molinos y la venta de frescos por cajas y ademas renta parqueo para carros ya que El Coyolito es una zona turistica y vienen muchas personas de la region y de otros paises, por este lugar es que se toman las lanchas para ir a la isla de Amapala.
 
Jose necesita el prestamo para comprar un nuevo motor para el molino ya que el que tiene le esta fallando y gasta casi lo mismo en repararlo que comprarse uno nuevo.

loans.use: compra de motor para molino y refrescos

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tchabodi

texts.fr: Monsieur Tchabodi a appris le métier de la couture ; il n’est pas marié et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge ; En 2005, il a ouvert son atelier de couture dans le quartier d’Agoè-Atsanvé à Lomé. Il est connu de beaucoup de personnes non seulement dans son quartier ; mais aussi des gens venant de loin attirés par ses performances dans la couture. Actuellement il dispose de deux apprentis tailleurs ; il a besoin d’une nouvelle machine à coudre pour vite satisfaire ses clients. C’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter une machine à broderie, 30 rouleaux de fils à broder et divers autres articles. Il compte sur sa longue expérience pour tenir ses engagements de remboursement.
texts.en:
Mr. Tchabodi learned the trade of dressmaking. He is not married and he is not financially responsible for any children. In 2005, he opened his sewing shop in the neighborhood of Agoè-Atsanvé in Lomé. Many people know him, not only in his neighborhood, but also people from afar who are drawn by his achievements in dressmaking.

Currently, he employs two apprentices. He needs a new sewing machine to quickly meet his customers' demand. This is the reason he is requesting a loan from WAGES, to buy an embroidery machine, 30 spools of embroidery floss and other various items. He is counting on his long experience to keep his promises of reimbursement.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine, thread and various items

loans.name: Chorro Para Arriba Group

texts.es:
El grupo solidario Chorro para arriba es originario del barrio Roberto Lara, que está ubicado frente al centro de la ciudad de Nindiri, divididos por la carretera principal que lleva de Managua a Masaya.

La coordinadora del grupo es doña Alejandra G. de 45 años de edad, quien se dedica a la elaboración de Bolis y Gelatinas (Refresco congelado embolsados en forma de rollo o rectángulo). Que distribuyen en las diferentes pulperías del departamento.

Alejandra trabaja con el apoyo de sus dos hijos mayores y su esposo quien es el que aprendió el oficio de unos amigos que le enseñaron el proceso de elaboración.  Trabajan según temporada, “Ésta es la temporada de mayor venta y por eso invertiremos en mayor cantidad” nos dice Alejandra.

Miriam R. vende golosinas y productos perecederos en las afueras de la Zona Franca ubicada en la carretera a Tipitapa; Sonia al igual que Miriam vende productos perecederos en la Zona Franca y Juana F. vende tortillas y comida en su casa de habitación.

loans.use: Compra de Materia Prima

loans.name: Rosa Elvia

texts.es:
Rosa es  otra socia del banco Comunal 3 de Mayo que se reúne cada quince días en la localidad de Picoaza una parroquia perteneciente a la ciudad de Portoviejo en la Provincia de Manabí. 

Rosa se caracteriza por ser una mujer luchadora, trabajadora y entregada a su familia, ella piensa siempre en el bienestar de los suyos  por eso acude a la fundación para solicitar un crédito que aportaría mucho para mejorar el negocio que ya tienen establecido.

Rosa es casada con Hernán Arteaga desde hace  30 años tienen tres hijos de 18, 26 y 28 años, se dedica a la venta de ropa  por ahora lo hacen  en un carro en el cual  junto a su esposo recorren las calles del lugar donde viven, vendiendo ropa y otros artículos.

Su vivienda es propia y está situada en el centro  de la localidad para sobrellevar su negocio,  en esta viven ya  diez años. Rosa sueña con arreglar su casa  para ahí también tener su negocio de venta de ropa que ella misma confecciona ya que es modista desde hace 26 años.
 
Rosa nos manifiesta que es un negocio familiar donde todos participan, su esposo hace fletes  y  también le  ayuda mucho en la venta de ropa, el es su gran apoyo acota.

El crédito que reciba de la fundación lo va a invertir en la compra de telas, hilos, cierres, botones, etc. para sus confecciones y para adquirir algo de bisutería para complementar sus prendas de vestir.
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the 3 de Mayo Communal Bank. They meet every 15 days in the Picoaza area, which is a parish belonging to the city of Portoviejo in the Manbí province. Rosa is a fighter and a hard-worker who is dedicated to her family. She always thinks of her family’s well being. That is why she comes to the foundation to ask for a loan, which will greatly contribute to her established business. Rosa has been married to Hernán Arteaga for 30 years. They have three children; ages 18, 26, and 28. She sells clothes. For now she sells in a car together with her husband . They travel the streets where they live selling clothes and other articles. Her house is her own, and it is situated in the center of the region in order to deal with her business. They have lived in this house for ten years. Rosa dreams of setting up her house to also have a business selling clothes there. She makes clothes herself, and she has been a dressmaker for 26 years. Rosa’s business is a family business where everyone participates. Her husband makes deliveries and also helps a lot selling clothes. He is a great help and a big advantage. She will use the loan that she receives to buy fabric, thread, zippers, and buttons, etc. to make clothes and to get some jewelry to compliment the clothes.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric, thread, zippers, and buttons, etc. to make clothes and  jewelry to compliment the clothes

loans.name: Qory Orcco - Pucyura Group

texts.es:
Los miembros del banco comunal “QORY ORCCO – PUCYURA”, están situados en el distrito de Anta en la provincia de Cusco; este banco está conformado por 10 miembros activos, estuvo ausente el señor Genaro, debido a un un problema de salud.
