Heidi Joy A. is from the village of P-3, Brgy. 25, Pandan Gingoog City. She is 27-years-old. Heidi Joy is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Heidi Joy owns and operates a food stall.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products in the local community like grilled pork, chicken parts, and a variety of snacks. Heidi Joy is just starting this business.

Heidi Joy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Heidi Joy is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family.

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

location.town: Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City, Mis. Or.

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea is 32 years old. She is married to Jose and they are living in the rural village of Bantay Solana, Cagayan with their children.  Their three children are: Angelica – 11 years old, Jenina – 10 years old and Jhun – 2 years old.  Her two eldest children are already in the elementary level. 

lea own and manages a small store in front of their house and it is open from 6:00 in the morning until 9:00 in the evening.  She hopes that her store will become progressive and in order to do this, she wanted to apply for a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5, 000. Her dreams of becoming a successful businesswoman in their community motivated Lea to work hard and save for the education of her children. Lea wanted them to finish their studies, thus she is doing her best to provide them with good education by managing her business well.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Mr. Mom Dok Village Bank Loan Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan consists of thirteen people, all living in Daeum Doung village.  Mr. Mom D. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. N. Sokha, is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it.  Mr. Mom D. decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products and also will use the rest of loan to buy a boat. He is 25-years-old and the father of a child who is too young to work or study. Two members who are pictured in the group are Mrs. N. Sokhorn and Mrs. Lonh Ary. 

Eleven members in this group loan are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more grocery products.

loans.name: Igor

texts.en: Igor is married with no children yet. He uses his car to offer taxi services in his city and between neighboring cities as well. Igor has been in this business for 5 years. Today more and more people use taxi services increasing number of potential clients. Using phone to get client’s orders Igor always have plenty of clients.  This business is the only source of income for his family. Igor would like to borrow 10,000 UAH to fix his car engine. As he makes more profit Igor hopes to increase his family living conditions.

loans.use: to fix the taxi engine

Lolita B. is from the village of P-1, Brgy. 25, Pandan Gingoog City. She is 34-years-old. Lolita, (seen on the right), is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a business venture together with Heidi Joy Abao, (left), as her business partner in the food sector making and selling food. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

location.town: Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City, Mis. Or.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 38 years old and a resident of Barangcuag, Angadanan, Isabela. She is a fish vendor in the wet market of Angadanan, Isabela. She needs additional business capital to be able to improve her business and generate more income for her family. For this, she is asking for a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos.

She has been working as a fish vendor for eight months and she keeps on hoping to make her business grow. She is making a gross income of 4,000 pesos (about $84 US) a week which she budgets as business capital and to provide for the needs of her family. Aside from fish selling, she also cooks different snacks like rice cakes, barbecue, and pasta in order to have extra income. She always believes that her hard work is the best foundation to gain more income and become successful someday for her family.

She is married to Jesus, a collector in a cosmetic company in Cauayan City. They have two children: the eldest is already in college while the second is a high school student.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Sobhiye

texts.en:
Sobhiye is a 31-year-old single woman living with her parents. She has owned a mini-market since 2008 in her town where she services the neighboring villages.

Today, Sobhiye is requesting to borrow $1200 to purchase additional merchandise in order to increase her sales and therefore her income.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en: Mrs. Nhor S. is a villager in Slaeng Kaung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. She is a 50-year-old widow with three children, one of whom is a cow middleman, while another is employed in a government department, and the third is a construction worker. Mrs. Nhor S. is applying for a loan to buy three more cows for her first child’s business.

loans.use: to buy three more cows for her first child’s business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella operates a general store business for ten years situated in their village in Barangcuag, Angadanan, Isabela. She is 48 years old and managing her store is her way of helping her husband to generate income to meet the needs of their family.  Aside from her store, they also have a farm as their major source of income. 

Her desire to expand her business motivates her to seek for financial assistance from the KIVA lenders a loan PHP17, 000 to make her store productive.  

Estrella is married to Canuto, a farmer and they were blessed with three children: the eldest daughter is already a fourth year college student; the second is a third year college student, and their youngest child is an IT graduate. Estrella is doing her best to improve her store and praying for the success of her children too.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Cely

texts.en:
Cely has managed a general store in her village for almost nine years. She generates a weekly gross income of PHP 6,000 that she wisely budgets for her family and for business maintenance. With her dream of developing her store, she is now requesting a loan of PHP 13,000 from Kiva lenders.

Cely is 54 years old and married to Roberto, a tricycle driver. They have no children and the couple lives a simple life in the village of Barangcuag, a rural but peaceful place in which to live.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites G. is from the village of Malangka, Gingoog City, in the Philippines. She is twenty-four years-old and married with three young children. Marites owns and operates a mini-restaurant called a "carenderia". While not the only revenue generator, the main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to local customers. Marites has run her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from it.

In 2009, Marites joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the business as a reserve for future emergencies.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food and drink for a restaurant

location.town: Malangka, Barangay 25, Gingoog City, Misamis Orien

loans.name: Roudayna

texts.en: Thirty-four-year-old Roudayna is married with four children. She has worked as a home-based food supplier for the past ten years. Today, Roudayna is applying for a loan of $1,200 to purchase merchandise with which to increase productivity in order to satisfy the heavy demands of her clients.

loans.use: Purchase food merchandise

loans.name: Chinita

texts.en:
A firm believer that “there’s wealth beneath the garbage”, Chinita G. is a 48-year-old garbage collector in Malibay, Pasay City.  She lives with her husband Eduardo, 54, an equally hardworking garbage collector.

Chinita and her husband have been a garbage collectors for more than twenty years.  She scours the village streets riding on her pedicab (rickshaw), collecting each household’s rubbish.  Her husband does the same routine in other areas.  Before they dump everything at the city’s waste disposal facility, they salvage anything of value, such as paper, bottles, and scrap metals, and sell these to buyers who in turn sell them to foundries and large junk shops.  After her daily garbage collection, she tends her ukay-ukay store (used clothing).  She earns more than P13,000 per month from these activities.

Chinita joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006.  This time, she has applied for a new P20,000 loan with CCT to purchase parts for the repair of her pedicab, and for her used clothing business.
 
It has been Chinita’s long sought-after dream to have her own house and business lot, including her own junk shop.  She also hopes that with her and her husband’s combined hard work, their children would be able to finish their studies. 

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Repair of pedicabs used in garbage collection and used clothes sales

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en: Mrs. Chhuon N. lives in Kdol village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Sek Sa Em, is a construction worker. Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than they need. Chhuon is asking for a loan to hire laborers to build her house. She is 46 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a casino club, while the others are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers to build her house.

loans.name: Kuch

texts.en: Kuch N., aged sixty, is married and lives in Takeo province with her three children. She and her husband sell dried and fermented fish at the market, making around US$7 each day, and are also supported by one of their children who works as a mechanic. Inflation has caused prices to soar in Cambodia, and recent hikes in oil and rice prices have caused economic struggles for many Cambodians. Looking for ways to increase her income and combat rising costs, Kuch N. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$1200 to purchase more fish to sell. She sees this loan as an opportunity to increase her income and to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Sout

texts.en: Sout C., 39, lives in Kandal province in Cambodia. Since 2007 she has been making and selling mats to earn a living, making approximately US$1.50 per day. Her husband is a construction worker and makes approximately US$4 every day. The couple has three children, one who is also a construction worker, and two who are students. Sout is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work on. This will reduce the transportation cost that he incurs each day.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Quirina

texts.en:
Quirina is 49 years old and she is married to Nicanor and they were blessed with two children: their children are both college graduates and they are now working as domestic helpers.  The eldest is in Canada while the youngest is in Dubai. Quirina and her husband were currently residing at Barangay Barangcuag Angadanan, Isabela. 

She manages a general store for almost ten years.  Her store has become their partner in supporting the financial needs of their children when they were studying.  At the moment, her store is now their sole source of income to support their daily needs at home since their two children is working miles away from them. She is requesting to avail the amount of PHP17, 000 as additional capital for the improvement of her business. She wanted her business to expand more and yield bigger income. On the other hand, their two children abroad sometimes sends them money remittances but Quirina and husband though the couple did not want to expect remittances from them because they will also soon have their own families to prepare for.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita F., 36, has been with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative since 2002 but embarked on establishing a hardware store only five years ago. Her husband Rogito, 39, is a plumber. All their four children are in school. They live in Maricaban, Pasay City.

Julita sells small spare parts for bicycles and motorcycles, as well as small industrial supplies. Her store is not large but since it is located on one of the city’s busy streets she is always busy attending to customers. She laments that she can’t have quality time with her children anymore, so she has hired two assistants to tend to customers. Julita now earns a net income of close to P300,000.00 a month.

Her loans from the cooperative and profits earned from her business have helped her to expand her store. She was also able to buy a family vehicle. In the future, she hopes to be able to establish another store in a different location. Julita is now teaching her children the value of hard work at a young age, as she wants them to inherit her business skills.

Julita is currently applying for a loan in the amount of P50,000.00 for the expansion of her business.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missions in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: business expansion

loans.name: Yon

texts.en: Mrs. Yon Y. is a villager in Dork Pour village in Takeo province. She sells rice and other foods in her store. She needs a loan to buy a variety of products to sell, in order to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Nou Min, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Yon Y. is 61 years old and the mother of a child who is a coconut seller. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy general products to sell

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie G. is from the village of Malangka, P-6 Brgy. 25, Gingoog City. She is 36 years old. Margie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Margie owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the business’s main income comes from selling specialty food products in the local community, such as longganisa, chorizo, hot dogs etc. Margie has had her business for over three years and earns approximately PHP2,400 a month.

In 2009, Margie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Margie is requesting a loan of PHP5000, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Margie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products to sell

location.town: Malangka, Barangay 25, Gingoog City, Misamis Orien

loans.name: Victorina

texts.en:
Victorina is a fish vendor in the wet market of Angadanan, Isabela. She is 32 years old and married to Dennis, a security guard. They have been blessed with four children: the eldest is now in grade six and the other three are not yet studying. They live in the village of Barangcuag, Angadanan, Isabela where most of the residents are engaged in farming.  
	
She is requesting a loan of PHP18,000 from KIVA lenders as additional business capital for her fish vending business. Aside from this, she also sells vegetables for additional income. Victorina is doing her best to become successful in the business. She hopes that her loan will be granted so she can use it to expand her farm and be a big help in sustaining her family's necessities.

loans.use: Additional Business Capital

loans.name: Hai

texts.en: Mrs. Hai H. lives in Dork Pour village in Takeo province. She is a housewife. Her husband, Mr. Nget Houk, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. This couple has four children, one of whom is a coconut seller while another is employed in a garment factory and the others are enrolled in the local school. Now Mrs. Hai H. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding and to buy a cart to transport the coconut to sell. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding and to buy a cart to transport the coconut to sell.

loans.name: Isabelito

texts.en:
Isabelito S., 44 years old, is a rice grower. He has four children who are all studying in school, the eldest being 15 years old. Currently, he tills a hectare of farm that he hopes could provide his family income to buy food and clothing and meet other basic needs.

He is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. He will use the loan to buy farming necessities, to obtain a bigger harvest. The loan will help him grow his income to realize his dreams for his children, which are for them to graduate college and find better jobs.

loans.use: Farm financing

loans.name: Jovito

texts.en:
Jovito is a tricycle operator for 16 years in their village in Barangcuag Angadanan, Isabela. He supported his family through his gained income from mere tricycle transport business. He is already 38 years old and married to Gina, a public school teacher in their village. They have one daughter, and she is already a nursery.  
  
He wanted to request for a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5, 000 that will be utilize for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle.  Jovito even maintain a farming business but most of the time, his time and efforts go to his transportation activities. He hopes that someday, he could able to give his family a better and successful living with the help of his chosen business for long years.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Lim P., 39, pictured with her husband, is married and lives with three of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She works as a farmer and typically makes US $5 every day, while her husband earns US $3 a day as a carpenter. They are also supported by their children, who are farm workers. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has also caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. In light of these times of economic difficulty, Lim P. is asking CREDIT for a loan of US $1,000 to aid her husband’s business. He currently works as a carpenter, and could make a lot more money if he opened up his own shop. She sees this loan as a way to increase her income and is confident that the business venture will be successful.

loans.use: To open a carpenter shop

loans.name: Concisa

texts.en:
Concisa N. is from the town of Katipunan. She is 54 years old. Concisa is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Concisa owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting rice for sale. Concisa has been engaged in her business for over 10 years with an approximated average monthly earnings of 5,000 PHP for these activities.

In 2006, Concisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. Concisa is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fertilizers and other farm supplies. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Concisa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Oeu

texts.en: Oeu S., 41, is married and resides with her husband (pictured) and three children in the Takeo province. To earn a living, she has been selling rice and palm sugar from her home. These activities are able to make her approximately US $2 of profit every day. Her husband is a construction worker and is able to earn US $7 per day. Due to the high transportation costs that her husband pays every day, Mrs. Oeu is asking for a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike. This will help reduce the transportation costs.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov S., 47, is a widow and has a business selling rice and coffee outside of her home. Living in Kampong Cham, she is able to make US$12 in revenue per day. She has three children living at home to support. Nov is requesting a loan of US$1000 from Kiva to expand her business. She would like to build a bigger stand and purchase more chairs and tables, in hope of increasing her business's turnover. However, Nov says that she faces some problems, including the high price of raw goods.

loans.use: To build a bigger stand and increase business turnover

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou C. is from the village of Brgy. 25, Pandan, Gingoog City. She is 33 years old. Marilou is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living Marilou owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the business’s main income comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Marilou has had her business for over five years and earns approximately PHP3,500 a month.

In 2009, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a new loan of PHP5000, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City, Mis. Or.

loans.name: Reynilda

texts.en:
Reynilda D. B., owns a small rice field in Vereula Agusan Del Sur. She has three choldren, 14 years old the eldest that are studying. She wanted to growe her rice farm because it the one which she hopes could proviD. her family an income to buyb food, clothing and other basic needs.

She would like to request a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and buy all the farming necessities. The loan will truly help her achieve better yield to support better her family.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Chhel

texts.en:
Chhel B., 49, lives in Takeo province where she is a professional clothes decorator. Since 1999, she has been using beads and other materials to make flower designs on women’s clothes to earn a living and typically makes US$4 each day. Her finished work is a kind of Khmer traditional dress and people wear it during Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year.

It takes around 7 to 10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive, too. Most of the people prefer hand-made rather than machine-made. Chhel said she learned how to decorate from her mother and she started doing this business before she was married.

Chhel’s husband is also a professional handicraft decorator and makes the same amount she does. This couple has six children and three of them are students.

Chhel is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase beads, silk and other materials to expand her business. Her daughter is shown in the photo because Chhel was not available.

loans.use: To buy beads, silk and other materials

loans.name: Emerita

texts.en:
Emerita patiently manages a village store for ten years.  Her family is also engaged in livestock and farming as their alternative source of income.  She wanted to avail a loan amounting to PHP14, 000 for the maintenance of her businesses so that she could generate higher income. Having the amount will enable her to buy stock of merchandise to retail in her store and feeds supply for her livestock business. However, her farming is being maintained through her generated income from her store. She believes that hard works is the key to success.  

Emerita is already a widow and she was left with her son named Norman.  She solely manages their family and she is quite sad because she was not able to provide a good education for her son.  At the moment, her son makes an earning out from his tricycle transport business.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Bayasgalan

texts.en:
Bayasgalan is 33 years old and lives with her husband, three daughters and son in Uvs province in Mongolia. All six members of the family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Not only do both Bayasgalan and her husband work in the family’s traditional shoe-making business, but the three girls help out as well. These traditional shoes are very popular during Mongolian holidays and celebrations.

Bayasgalan began her business in 2003, and only made one type of traditional Mongolian shoe, the Bayad. However, after experiencing success with the first type of shoe, she expanded her business to not only include several different types of traditional shoes, but employed two assistants as well.

Bayasgalan has the ability to not only create quality shoes, but beautiful shoes as well. Her dream is to one day own her own shoe-making factory and be able to hire more employees. She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase a sewing machine and materials in order to increase sales.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and raw materials

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo S., 54, is married and lives with her husband and five of her children in Kampong Cham province.

To earn a living, Keo S. makes and sells cake and sugarcane and is able to make approximately US$2 of profit every day. This cake is made from sticky rice and she puts it into bamboo before she cooks it.

Keo S.’s husband is a garment officer and earns US$2 per day as well. The family is also supported by two of the children who work as garment factory workers.

Keo S. is asking for a loan of US$1,200 to purchase rice, ingredients and bamboo so that she can increase the number of cakes she makes to sell every day.

loans.use: To purchase rice, ingredients and bamboo

loans.name: Mary Cris

texts.en:
Mary Cris owns and manages a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field. She has four children, 9 years old the eldest, that she truly puts all her attention to and wishes them to do well in their studies.

Mary Cris needs additional capital to run her business. Because of this, she would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI).

It is not only for business that she is applying for a loan from CEVI, but also because she heard that CEVI provides education and insurance to all its borrowers. Now, she has started to like the credit program of CEVI and has decided to obtain more CEVI loans in the future.

loans.use: To use for farm financing

loans.name: Bayarkhuu

texts.en: Bayarkhuu is 38 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Uvs province of Mongolia.  He and his family live in their own home with two children attending high school while the younger two children attend primary school.  Bayatkhuu and his wife operate a grocery trading business in the local market where they import between 3,000,000 and 6,000,000 tugrug (~2100-4200 USD) of products per month from both China and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  They started this business in 2002 and quickly gained a reputation as great customer service providers. Bayatkhuu wants to grow his business so that he may own his own grocery shop and so that he can send his children to university. He is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~2800 USD) loan so that he can purchase a greater amount and variety of groceries for his business.

loans.use: purchase a greater amount and variety of groceries for his business.

loans.name: Arcelie

texts.en:
Arcelie manages a general store business in Babanuang San Manuel, Isabela. She is already 46 years old and already married. She wanted to request for a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP7, 000 in order to develop her business. Aside from her general store she is also managing a beauty parlor business. She is blessed with two children: Mel Joseph and Cheny. 

She has been doing her best in the business for already 13 years. Her business income which is around PHP2, 000 a day is carefully budget to meet the needs of their family and for the maintenance of her business. is also saving some of her income for the tuition fees and allowances of her children. Arcelie dreams to have a better family living by patiently managing her beauty parlor and general store business.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Rudy

texts.en: Rudy S. is from the village of P-1, Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City. He is 44 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Rudy owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling a variety of different products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rudy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his children’s education. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Barangay 25, Pandan, Gingoog City, Mis. Or.

loans.name: Miroslav

texts.en: Miroslav is married with two children. For the last two years he has run a business renting office space in a building that he co-owns. Affordable prices and good customer service attract clients and make his business a success. Miroslav would like to borrow money to do some final work inside the building so that he is able to rent out all the space. He is requesting 11,000 UAH to complete the work.

loans.use: To finish the interior of the building

loans.name: Katumba 2 – United Atusalirwe Gertrude Group

texts.en: A. Gertrude is 36 years old, and is single with two school-aged children. She also takes care of one dependent. Gertrude has owned a retail shop for over four years. She is using her loan to add stock, such as sugar, salt, soap, maize flour, etc., to expand her business. She is a very hardworking woman and hopes her business prospers.

loans.use: To purchase stock such as sugar, salt, soap, maize flour, etc.

loans.name: Munkhtogtokh

texts.en: Munkhtogtokh is 42 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Uyurkhangai province of Mongolia. The three oldest children attend high school, while the youngest child is at home.  Munkhtogtokh makes furniture in his own shop near the family home. He started this business in 1996 and has since made quality furnishings for the people of his town. Munkhtogtokh wants to one day own a stall in the large central market where he can expand his customer base, sell more furniture and further improve his family’s financial situation. In the 13 years of owning his business, Munkhtogtokh has not only gained experience and knowledge in making quality furniture products, but he has also gained business knowledge. He is requesting a 3,960,000 tugrug (~2800 USD) loan to buy more wood and furniture making supplies for his business.

loans.use: to buy more wood and furniture making supplies for his business.

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em M., 38, is married and lives with two of her children in the Takeo province. She and her husband (pictured) are farmers who typically make about US$2 each day and are. Besides farming, her husband also works as a middle man selling cows. This allows him to earn about US$5 a week. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Em M. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase fertilizer and raise cows. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: buy cows

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean manages a general store business in the rural community of Bantay Solana, Cagayan. She is 34 years old and is married to Samson A.. They are blessed with two children – Jinkie, 13, and Mikee, 12 – who are both studying. The couple consider their children as their treasure in life so they are taking very good care of them.

Jean wanted to apply for additional capital from Kiva lenders to further improve her store. She is applying for the amount of 5,000 PHP, which will be of great help.

loans.use: As additional capital

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Phorn S., 47, is married and lives with two of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She works a farm with her husband and typically makes $3 USD each day. Besides farming, her husband also operates a horse cart taxi. This business earns him an additional $5 USD a day.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Phorn S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, Phorn is asking for a loan of $700 USD, which she will use to purchase fertilizer for the farm and also make a new investment in a charcoal business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and invest in a charcoal business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn T., 29 years old is a rice farmer. She has three children, her eldest is just 4 years old and is now ready for preschool. Currently, she owns a 2 -hectare farm and 2 carabaos, a farm animal used in plowing the rice field.

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to fund her farm and pay the laborer who helped prepare the soil ready-for-planting.

She said, she likes the CEVI credit program because it has only 2% interest rate which is very low and easy to repay.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Keang

texts.en: Keang K., 26, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who typically makes about US$1.5 every day, while her husband earns US$3 each day as a recycler. This couple has two young children living at home to support. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Porn Samorn included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$1000 for her husband to reinvest in recycling business.

loans.use: To reinvest in recycling business.

loans.name: Rona Lorraine

texts.en:
Rona Lorraine is managing a grocery store located in Echague public market. She is 29 years old and still single.  She is very eager to improve her business and with her strong determination to succeed in life, she now wanted to expand her grocery to further generate bigger capital to help in providing the needs of her family.  

Rona wanted to request for a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP25, 000 that she will use for her grocery store. She is hoping that she could buy additional merchandise for her store to meet the demands of her customers.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Uuganbayar

texts.en: Uuganbayar is 26 years old and lives with his wife and two-year-old daughter in Zavhan province in Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Uuganbayar owns and operates a shoe repair business. He began his business in 2008 in his home, but has since moved to a rented workspace which gives him greater access to more customers. Uuganbayar’s dream is to grow his business so that he and his family can build their own home. He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to buy more repair supplies and tools for his business.

loans.use: To buy more repair supplies and tools

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 26 year old man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon. Ahmad has been working as a motorcycle repairer since 2003. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and spare parts for his work. This is the first time that Ahmad has requested a loan.
Ahmad is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Ahmad first started his business, he had financial issues. He decided on doing his business because of his experience, as well as he wanted to have an independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding.

loans.use: To purchase tools and spare parts for his work.

loans.name: Katumba-2-United Nyangoma Peace Group

texts.en:
N. Peace is twenty-nine years old, single with one child, and the child is in school. Herself, she is an engineer operating a garage dealing with car mechanics. She has been in the mechanics business for over ten years.

Peace is using the loan to buy more car paint and spare parts to be the best in her business. This will help her expand the business. She is a hardworking woman whose future hope is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house of her own.

loans.use: To buy more car paint and spare parts

loans.name: Mary Kerubo

texts.en:
Mary is 47 years old and married to Samuel who is a civil servant working for one of the goverment ministries. They have two children, Charles and Catherine who are 25 and 23 respectively.

Mary runs a retail shop in a densely populated area with middle level customers who are loyal to her due to her good rapport with them. 

Mary has no credit history and was introduced to KADET staff when they conducted a marketing promotion in her area of operation and after organizing some business partners they formed a group where she is the founder of the group.

She has applied for a loan which she plans to increase her stock including rice and soft drinks which is in high demand at the moment and with the extra profits she plans to pay school fees for her daughter Catherine.

Mary's hopes and dreams are to expand her business to a wholesale supplier within and outside markets.

Mary believes she is hardworking, friendly and forward looking.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Increasing of stock incliding rice and soft drinks

loans.name: Suzan

texts.en:
Suzan is a 34-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their child.

Suzan owns a hairdressing salon and she also sells beauty products. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new equipment and beauty products for her work. This is her third loan and she has always repaid on time.

Suzan is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients and is aware of new hairstyles. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. Suzan decided on doing her business because of her experience and when she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. In the future, she plans on expanding her work.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment and beauty products

loans.name: Soeung

texts.en:
Soeung S. is 30 years old and resides in Kampong Cham province. She has four children living at home to support.

To earn a living, Soeung S. sells second-hand clothes at the market and is able to make about US$6 of profit every day. Her husband is a worker at the port and makes US$13 each day.

Soeung S. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to expand her inventory of clothes.

loans.use: To expand her inventory

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en: Cheryl B. is from the village of Usocan. She is 37 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Cheryl owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Cheryl joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Cheryl is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Asaad

texts.en:
Asaad is a 48 year old man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Asaad has owned a grocery store since 1980. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. Asaad has been a microcredit client for eleven years now and has always paid on time. 
His previous loans helped him diversify his merchandise and improve his work by enlarging his work. Asaad is special in his work because he owns a big variety of products. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Asaad first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Niza

texts.en: Niza D. is from the village of Pandan, Gingoog City. She is 41 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Niza owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Niza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Niza is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Naranbaatar

texts.en: D. Naranbaatar is 26 years old and lives with his parents in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. He  currently operates a wooden products and furniture production business in his town. He produces materials  and wooden furniture used in gers, traditional Mongolian nomadic tent homes. He designs and produces the furniture himself and has one assistant that helps him. He owns a shipping container at the local market where his mother works to sell his products. Naranbaatar started his ger material and furniture production business in 2004 with the support of his father. His father, an experienced craftsman, taught him all the techniques and skills needed to make wooden products. However, after suffering a stroke, his father had to give up the trade and currently doesn't work. When he started, they  produced furniture based on customer orders, but now take orders and produce furniture for sale at the shipping container. For the future, Naranbaatar hopes to continue to grow and expand his business. He says, "With the growth of my business, I hope to take care of my parents as long as I can.”. He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) loan to purchase wood and supplies for his ger and wooden furniture business.

loans.use: to purchase wood and supplies for his ger and wooden furniture business.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam S. is 39 years old and resides with her husband and four of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She is a housewife living at home cooking for the family member. Her husband sells ice-cream and ice to earn a living and is able to make about US$6.5 of profit every day and is supported by two of the children who are blacksmith and a garment factory worker. Sam S. would like to take out a loan of US$600 for her husband to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand the ice-cream's business.

loans.name: Peng

texts.en: Peng S., 25, is a professional decorates handicrafts living at home in the Takeo province. Since 2006, she has been using beads and other materials to make flower on woman clothes to earn a living and typically making US$3 each day. Decorates handicrafts is a kind of Khmer traditional dress and people wear it during Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7-10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive too. Most of the people prefer hand made than machine made. She said she knows how to decorate from her mother and she started doing that business since she not married yet. Her husband is a mechanic fixing motorbike. He typically makes US$3 each day. This couple has two young children. Peng is asking for a loan of US$1200 to purchase mechanic tools for her husband.

loans.use: buy machanic tools

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em S., 52, is married and lives with four of her children in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer and also sells grocery items, typically making about US$2 each day. Her husband (pictured) has a business charging batteries from home. This business allows him to make US$8 in revenue every day.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Em S. included.

In light of these economic difficulties, Em S. is asking for a loan of US$1,200 to purchase a truck so that her family can transport goods from market to sell and also batteries. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase a truck

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en:
Shirly O. is from the village of Cebulin. She is 62 years old. Shirly is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Shirly owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Shirly has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Shirly joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Shirly is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Shirly from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Roychu

texts.en:
Roychu M. is from the village of Gingoog City. He is 43 years old. Roychu is married and has two school-aged children.

Roychu owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community.   He has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Roychu joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand his product offering.

Roychu is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This loan will be his 3rd from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian K. sells groceries such as milk Milo and soft drinks at Elmina near Liverpool.  Vivian has received junior high school education.  She is married and has six dependants’ children. Her husband works with u.c.c. press. Vivian has been selling groceries such and soft drinks since the year 1989. She supports husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more groceries and soft drinks to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy more groceries and soft drinks to sell.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more groceries and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Chhan

texts.en: Chhan K., 34, is a true entrepreneur who has a business selling fish at the market. She typically makes about $5 US a day. She has a little child living at home to support. Her husband has been a horse cart driver since 2006 and is able to make $5 US per day as well. Chhan K. is asking for a loan to purchase more fish to sell at the market. This will allow her to make more money to support her family.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Isekahingu United Saada Kabadaki Group

texts.en: Saada K. is fifty years old business woman representing her group. She is a widow with two children and she also has a dependant who is an orphan in school. She sells firewood and it is over five years in the business. She is using the loan in order to increase on the size of her business by purchasing much more firewood for big profit return. She is very hard working and courageous woman who is encouraging young women also to work hard in her community. Her future plan is constructing a house.

loans.use: To increase on the size of her business by purchasing much more firewood for big profit return.

loans.name: Takouhi

texts.en:
Takouhi has been selling clothes and lingerie from her house. She is a 37-year-old woman who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with her husband and their child. Takouhi is known for selling good quality products. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When Takouhi first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. She decided on this business because she wanted to have independent work and supplement her family’s income.

Takouhi requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her sales during Ramadan. Takouhi has been a microcredit client for five years now and has always paid on time. Her previous loans helped her diversify her merchandise. In the future, she plans on improving her work, as well as helping her husband open a restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Fernanda

texts.en:
Fernanda A. is from the village of Cebulin. She is 36 years old. Fernanda is married and has 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Fernanda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Fernanda is just starting this business.

In 2006, Fernanda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fernanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Fernanda is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Fernanda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is a 33 year married with 4 children aged between 6 and 19 years.All her children go to school. Florence resides and owns a two roomed house where she staying with five people. There is electricity and no piped water at home. Florence takes care of additional family members aged 6 and 9 yaers  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala and works seven days a week.  She receives 10 customers a day. Florence owns a retail shoping selling home products goods and other soft drinks in Kamwokya kifumbira and sells to all categories of people.  She incurs extra transport costs to and from shopping.  The major challenges she faces in her business are transportation and medication and feeding the family.  Florence has been with MCDT for 10 years servicing her twentieth loan working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of soda and beer Florence is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning a permanent business structure and also build a house from the available profits

loans.use: To buy more Merchandise and soft drinks

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en:
Ziad has owned a grocery store since 2003. He is a 37-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Ziad carries a large variety of products. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Ziad first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing this business because he wanted to have independent work.

Ziad requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is his third cycle and he has always repaid on time. His previous loans helped him diversify his merchandise. In the future, he plans on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Wael

texts.en:
Wael is a 20 year old man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon. Wael has owned a generator for three years. He offers electricity to the houses in his surroundings when the electricity shot off. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a bigger and more powerful generator for his work. This is her third cycle and he has always on time. 
His previous loans helped him improve his work. Wael is special in his work because he works 24/7. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Wael first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent work. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase a generator for his work.

loans.name: Hang

texts.en: Hang C. is 26 years old and resides in the Kampong Cham province. She has one young child living at home to support. To earn a living, she has been selling second-hand clothes at the market and is able to make about US$5 in profit every day, while her husband, pictured here, is a car mechanic and makes US$10 each day. Hang is asking for a loan of US$1000 to expand her inventory of clothes.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of clothes

loans.name: Agob

texts.en:
Agob is a 64 year old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Agob has owned a coffee shop since 1984. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a new coffee machine and pay his children's school tuition. Agob has been a microcredit client for eleven years now and has always paid on time.

His previous loans helped him diversify his merchandise and improve his coffee shop. Agob's work is special because his coffee shop is cozy. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Agob first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent job. In the future, he plans on expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase a new coffee machine and pay his children's school tuition.

loans.name: Warlita

texts.en:
Warlita C. is from the village of Danao. She is 65 years old. Warlita is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Warlita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Warlita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 1999, Warlita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Warlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Warlita is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 17th loan taken out by Warlita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Toeung

texts.en: Toeung S., 47, is a widow living in the Takeo province with her two children. She sells dessert and is supported by one of the children who work in the garment factory. Toeung S. is asking for a loan of US$400 to make a new investment. She will buy perfume items and resell it for a profit.

loans.use: buy perfume items

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. sells maize and banku: she goes to the market buys maize in large quantities and uses some for banku at Elmina near Liverpool Street.  Esi has no educational background.  She is married and has six dependants. Her husband is a fisherman. Esi has been selling sells maize and banku since the year 1999. She supports the husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more maize and use some for banku. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a land.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more maize and use some for banku.

loans.name: Wobkine

texts.en:
Wobkine is a 44 year old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Wobkine has been working as a jewelry designer for three years. He produces bracelets, necklaces, earrings and other jewelry depending on the fashion and the demand. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a new machine to expand his production. This is his second loan and he has always repaid on time.

His previous loan helped him improve his work. Wobkine's work is special because he produces nice and trendy jewelry. His clients are his friends, neighbors and traders. When Wobkine first started his business he had family issues. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent job. In the future, he plans on expanding his work by selling throughout the Arab countries.

loans.use: To purchase a new machine to expand his production.

loans.name: Saom

texts.en: Saom S. is 30 years old and resides with her husband in the Kampong Cham province. Since 2006, she has been selling porridge to earn a living, and is able to make about US$10 in revenue every day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver who typically makes US$5 of profit each day. This couple has two young children living at home to support. Saom S. is asking a loan of US$1000 to make a new investment. She would use this money to buy and resell rubber. (Saom is pictured with her husband from home)

loans.use: To buy and resell rubber.

loans.name: Jasmin

texts.en:
Jasmin is a member of the Idunda borrower group in Kihesa,Iringa. She is 18 year old , she is married and a mother of 1 child. Her child is 1 year old.

Jasmin has owned a food business selling bites for 1 year, she works 9 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Jasmin`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Jasmin hopes to save more money, pay school,and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for her business

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is a 40 year old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Jean has been working as a hairdresser for nine years. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase beauty products for his salon. Jean has been a microcredit client for eight years now and has always paid on time. 

His previous loans helped him improve his salon. Jean's work is special because he does a good job and is aware of the new hair style fashions. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Jean first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent job. In the future, he plans on expanding his work by doing other aesthetic services.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products for his salon.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia P. is from the village of Danao. She is 58 years old. Lucia is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lucia owns and operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Lucia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Lucia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Lucia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Lucia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Soung

texts.en: Soung S., 59, is a widow living in Phnom Penh with her two children. Since 2007, she has been selling groceries to earn a living and is able to make about $7 US every day. One of her children, who works as a construction worker, helps support her. Soung is asking for a loan of$1000 to expand her grocery stand.

loans.use: To expand her grocery stand.

loans.name: Un

texts.en: Un K., 45, is a widowed farmer, living in the Takeo province with three children. She makes about US$3 every day, but it is not enough to support her family, so two of her children send money from their work in the garment factories every month. The weather conditions have not been favorable for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also forced food prices to rise rapidly. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Un K. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more farmland to grow rice. She sees this new rice field as a great economic opportunity for her. She believes that the rice field can help to both increase her income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: buy more farmland

loans.name: Peace

texts.en:
Peace N. is 37 years old ,wisdow with two children  with the following years old :
12 and 9.
She lives in  Rurindo district,southern province of Rwanda where she owns sewing machine.
Peace starts her business everyday from 8h00 AM to 7h00PM;the purpose of this loan requested in Vision Finance Company is to expand her business through purchasing the many new sewing machines .
Before requesting this new  loan  she was not able get more profit ,by now she hopes to earn extra profit which will help her to save money so that she gets  more food for her children and to pay  school fees for them.

loans.use: Purchasing new sewing machines

loans.name: Kitonzi United Kunihira Eflazia Group

texts.en: K. Eflazia is a 50-year-old single mother of five and guardian of three dependents. Two of her children currently attend school. Eflazia has sold fresh food for over 10 years. She wants to use this loan to expand her business's stock by purchasing more foods such as bananas, vegetables, tomatoes, and onions. She is a hardworking and promising businesswoman whose dreams include educating her children and constructing a permanent house.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh food to expand her business's selection of goods.

loans.name: Gracel

texts.en:
Gracel S. is from the village of Danao. She is 22 years old. Gracel is married. To make a living, Gracel owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Gracel has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Gracel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gracel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Gracel is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Gracel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Isekahungu United Bamanyisa Topista Group

texts.en: B. Topista is forty-seven years old, the chairperson of Isekahungu United group. She is married with eight children and three of them are in school. She owns a retail shop which she has been operating for over ten years. She is requesting for the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, etc mostly essentials. The loan will help her improve upon her business which will enable her pay school fees for her children. She is a hard working business woman. Her future plan is seeing her children through. There group target is to struggle for the better future of their children

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, salt, soap, cooking oil, etc mostly essentials.

loans.name: Merna

texts.en:
Merna M. is from the village of Danao. She is 44 years old. Merna is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Merna owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Merna has been engaged in her business for over 27 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Merna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Merna is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Merna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family.

loans.name: Mugoma Kweterana Joyce Baguma Kyawera Group

texts.en:
Joyce B. K. is a 50-year-old widow. She has four children, of which two are in school. She also has three dependents, all of whom attend school. Joyce sells fresh and dry beans. She has run this business, which shifts with the season, for over 10 years. 

Joyce wants to use this loan to increase the stock of beans she offers. Among other things, she wants to purchase three additional sacks of dry beans. She also hopes to purchase iron sheets for her house. Joyce is very hardworking and is a creative asset for her community. Her dream is to see prosperity come her way.

loans.use: To increase the stock of beans she offers.

loans.name: Tabita Group

texts.en: John is forty – one years old. He is married and has give birth to three children, all in school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. John is a trader. He trades in bags of maize. He is the leader of a trust bank group called Tabita. The group members are engaged either in farming and/or trading activities. They supply to retailers and chop bar operators in their town and nearby communities. They want a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en: Georgina A. sells groundnut past: she buys groundnut in sacks roast them and blend it into paste to be sold at Elmina near the new market.  Georgina has been to a commercial school.  She is married and has four children. Her husband is a pensioner. Georgina has been selling groundnut past since 1999. She supports the husband in the payment of school fees and payment of apartment. Her loan will be used to buy more bags of groundnut and beans to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards building a land to build on.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more bags of groundnut and beans to sell.
